metadata.case_name: Atic Industries Ltd. & Ors. v. Their Workmen

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner of Labour, Ahmedabad, by order dated February 19, 1966 referred nine demands by workmen of Atic Industries Ltd. for adjudication to Industrial Tribunal, Gujarat in Reference I.T. No. 65 of 1966.

Demand No. 4 by workmen of Atic Industries Ltd.: All workmen using S.T. Bus Service paid Rs. 20/- per month as Bus Allowance; cyclists from places without bus Rs. 15/- per month; train users Rs. 10/- per month.
Industrial Tribunal by Award Part I dated September 27, 1967 disposed demands Nos. 1,2,3,6,9; by Award Part II dated November 15, 1967 disposed demands Nos. 4,5,7,8.
Tribunal directed Atic Industries Ltd. to pay 15 paise per day to every employee staying 5 miles or more from village Atul, effective January 1, 1968, not payable on leave days.
Atic Industries Ltd. filed Civil Appeal No. 742 of 1968 challenging grant of allowance.
Workmen filed Civil Appeal No. 2086 of 1968 challenging Award Parts I & II, restricted by Supreme Court order dated September 24, 1968 to transport allowance.
Deputy Commissioner by order dated June 30, 1966 referred nine demands of Atul Products Ltd. workmen to Tribunal in Reference I.T. No. 60 of 1966.
Demand No. 6 by Atul Products Ltd. workmen: Company provide free transport or pay Rs. 15/- per month till provided.
Tribunal by Award Part II dated October 16, 1967 rejected free transport but directed 15 paise per day for employees 5 miles+, effective December 1, 1967, not on leave.
Atul Products Ltd. filed Civil Appeal No. 809 of 1968 challenging direction.
Both companies in village Atul, manufacture dyes and chemicals; majority workmen from 5-10 miles away, e.g., Bulsar, due to lack of local labour.
Public transport inadequate: S.T. buses irregular, bus fare 40 paise/trip (80 paise/day round trip from Bulsar).
Companies: Good road, adequate S.T. bus and train service available; most workmen local, knew to bear own transport costs.
Cynamid India Ltd. (pharma in Atul) paying 15 paise/day (>5 miles); Tribunal increased to 37 paise (>5 miles), 12 paise (3-5 miles) in 1966 award.
Companies provide accommodation to ~25 workmen at nominal rent; others nearby, no transport need.

legal_issues.text: Whether Industrial Tribunal had jurisdiction to direct payment of transport allowance after rejecting demand for free transport facilities.
Whether employer is obligated to provide transport facilities or bear transport expenses of workmen commuting to work.
Whether grant of 15 paise per day transport allowance to workmen staying 5+ miles from Atul is justified, considering region-cum-industry principle and circumstances.

petitioner_arguments.text: Not function/duty of employer to provide transport or allowance; workmen knew to bear own costs; dearness allowance revised suffices.
No jurisdiction: Demand for allowance only interim till free transport provided; rejecting free transport ends claim.
Bus fare included in cost of living index/DA; housing/medical not employer's duty.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Ahmedabad Mill Owners Assn. v. Textile Labour Assn.; Patna Electric Supply Co. v. Patna Electric Supply Workers Union

petitioner_arguments.text: No lunch allowance normally if fair wages/DA linked to cost of living.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Remington Rand of India Ltd. v. Workmen

respondent_arguments.text: Demand alternative: free transport or Rs.15/- allowance; public transport inadequate, high cost (80 paise/day); parity with Cynamid India Ltd. in same region.
Tribunal rejected free transport due to available public system, not absolute non-liability; should consider allowance separately.
Uniformity in region (industry-cum-region); Tribunal awarded partial relief (15 paise vs 80 paise).
Bus fare not in Ahmedabad cost of living index.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Cost of Living Index Numbers in India (Labour Bureau)

respondent_arguments.text: Enhance to 80 paise/day or Cynamid rate.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal had jurisdiction: Demand alternative (free transport OR allowance); rejection of free transport due to available public system, not absolute non-liability.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Latter part survives as alternative claim.

court_reasoning.text: Employer not normally obligated for full transport, but Tribunal can impose reasonable obligation in social justice interest, per industry-cum-region principle.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Uniformity avoids labour migration; akin to partial medical burden.

court_reasoning.text: 15 paise/day justified: Partial relief (workmen share cost); considers DA/wages fixed knowing transport claim; moderate vs demands; only for verified distant workers, no leave days.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cynamid practice relevant; not unreasonable (Rs.4.50/month max).

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes precedents: Housing different; lunch if no distant need; bus fare not always in index.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal can create new obligations reasonably.

holdings.text: Industrial Tribunal has jurisdiction to award transport allowance as alternative after rejecting free transport.
Employer may be directed to pay limited transport allowance in proper case for industrial harmony, per region-cum-industry.
Grant of 15 paise/day to workers 5+ miles from Atul upheld as reasonable.

precedents_cited.citation: Published in State Gazette on September 3, 1966
precedents_cited.relevance: Basis for claim; awarded higher allowance; rejection grounds for free transport applied.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ahmedabad Mill Owners Association v. Textile Labour Association
precedents_cited.relevance: Bus fare usually in cost of living index, but not in Ahmedabad.

precedents_cited.case_name: Patna Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Patna Electric Supply Workers Union
precedents_cited.relevance: Housing Govt duty; Tribunal can impose new obligations.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohammed and Sons v. Their Workmen
Remington Rand of India Ltd. v. Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: No lunch allowance if fair wages/DA; but recognizes limited employer medical obligation.

precedents_cited.case_name: New Maneck Chowk Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd. v. Textile Labour Association
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunal jurisdiction conditioned by law to impose obligations.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Delegation to Deputy Commissioner for references.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed all three appeals, confirmed Tribunal awards directing 15 paise per day transport allowance to workmen staying 5+ miles from Atul village, payable only on working days when commuting, not on leave.

key_quotes.text: "there should be justification for a Company being made to provide free transport only if a sound public transport system did not exist or was not conveniently available."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Ground for rejecting free transport but allowing allowance.

key_quotes.text: "the foundation of the principle of industry-cum-region is that as far as possible, there should be uniformity of conditions of service in comparable concerns in the industry in the region"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "a Tribunal will have jurisdiction in a proper case to call upon an employer to shoulder a part of the burden regarding medical expenses incurred by his workman"
key_quotes.speaker: court
